noun.description: The reversion of property to the state, or (in feudal law) to a lord, on the owner's dying without legal heirs.
examples: the Crown's right of escheat was lost

verb.description: (of land) revert to a lord or the state by escheat.
examples: a private chase which had escheated to the King

origin: Middle English: from Old French eschete, based on Latin excidere fall away, from ex- out of, from + cadere to fall.
